summary: AI-powered education and skilling platform that bridges the gap between academic CS curriculums and industry expectations. Focuses on teaching architectural logic, problem-solving, and practical system design (not just syntax). Includes interactive frontend UI to visualize why certain approaches (e.g., BST vs flat array, Git conflict resolution) are used in real-world scenarios.
architectural_notes: Interactive, visually rich frontend is a priority — use animations and diagrams to illustrate CS concepts
Platform focus: teach reasoning and architectural thinking, not just syntax checking
imageRequirements:
## Required Images
- Dark hero banner with circuit board pattern, glowing nodes, and subtle neon green grid lines (hero-banner.dim_1400x400.png)
- Minimalist neon-green brain-chip icon on dark background (logo-icon.dim_128x128.png)
- Abstract dark background texture with faint hexagonal grid pattern in deep charcoal (bg-texture.dim_1920x1080.png)

existing_features.title: Create a visually rich, interactive dashboard as the main landing page showing the student's learning path, progress stats, and quick-access cards for each module (Architectural Logic, Data Structures, System Design, Git Mastery). Use a dark-tech aesthetic with accent neon highlights, bold typography, and animated progress indicators.

Build an interactive Data Structure Visualizer module that lets students compare algorithmic approaches side-by-side (e.g., BST vs flat array search). Animate step-by-step traversal with highlighted nodes/elements, display time complexity callouts, and explain with contextual 'why this matters in industry' tooltips.

Build an AI Mentor panel that displays contextual explanations for any code problem or architectural decision. The mentor responds with 'why' reasoning (not just correctness), structured as: Approach Chosen → Trade-offs → Real-world Analogy → Better Alternative (if any). Mentor responses are stored in the backend and retrieved per session.

Build a Git Conflict Resolution Simulator module. Present the student with a realistic merge conflict scenario (base, ours, theirs versions shown in a split diff editor). Student resolves the conflict by editing the merged output. The system validates the resolution and provides step-by-step guided hints if the student is stuck.

Build an Industry Challenge Feed that lists real-world system design and architectural tasks (e.g., 'Design a URL shortener', 'Choose the right DB for a ride-sharing app'). Each challenge card shows difficulty, estimated time, and a 'Start Challenge' CTA. Challenges are stored and retrieved from the backend.

Apply a cohesive dark-tech visual theme across the entire application: deep charcoal/near-black backgrounds, electric green and cyan neon accents, monospace + sans-serif font pairing, subtle grid or circuit-pattern backgrounds, glowing card borders on hover, and smooth page transition animations. The design should feel like a professional developer IDE meets a learning platform.
